The historical wild poliovirus cases in Africa since 2011 have been 257, 128, 274, 44, 0 (ending in 2015). The trend has been noticeably downwards. Afganistan and Pakistan, however, continue to have infected each year. Their infected rate has been (since 2011) 278, 95, 107, 334, 74 (ending 2015). Thru June 28th of 2016, there have been 18 confirmed wild cases in Afganistan and Pakistan, compared to 29 the prior year during the same time period. Although the level of infected in the neighboring region is low and the region Africa has been without infection for 22 months (Aug '14 - Jun '16), there is still risk of infection, in my opinion.  I do not know of a way to quantify the risk, so I'll think in terms of 10% of risk. I think it is less than a 50% chance they get infected, probably less than 20%, but more than 10%. So i'll split the difference.

Polio eradication efforts appear to have been tremendously successful in Africa (the last documented case of polio was in 2014)--much more so than in the hinterlands of Afghanistan and Pakistan, where suspicion of health workers hampers international efforts.  Yet, despite the very mixed political stability of African regimes, this issue does not seem to be as much of a barrier.  If the continent were more stable, I'd give its chances of remaining free of polio a higher rating.  However, polio has a variable incubation period (with a case report as long as 12 years!) and does not cause symptoms in the majority of people who are infected.   The human infected pool could still be significant in Africa, and any of those people could, in theory, begin to display symptoms if their immune systems were to be compromised, as with HIV, for example.
Still wild poliovirus free in Africa with less than 9 months to go!
Still wild poliovirus free in Africa with less than 9 months to go!

(Sadly, I didn't save the link.) I'm guessing that these organizations (UN or WHO was among them) are generally conservative about predictions like this.

Poliovirus lives in water - 100 days and in faeces - 6 months. The virus is resistant to freezing, dry weather is killing, the source of infection - man. Different sources have  different views on the carriers of the virus (infectious or not, the man who recovered), for the monkeys have some discussion.  Since 2014 cases of wild polio were not registered in Africa. Real and acting wild source of poliovirus are Afganistan and Pakistan, people from those countries usually travel in other continents. Also, the fight against polio continues worldwide, but odds for poliovirus in Africa is existing, as the population is large and there is good condition for an infection spread.

Stability is likely to result in more outbreaks, not fewer, as transport opportunities increase. Given increasingly stable state of Somalia  but no subsequent outbreaks then it is unlikely that the original source is still viable (whatever it was)
Still wild poliovirus free in Africa with almost 9 months to go!

I gave Africa, a notoriously underdeveloped and disease-riddled continent a high chance of not having a single case of polio for a few reasons. In 1988, the Global Polio Eradication initiative was created in response to the astonishingly high rate of polio in the world. This gained a lot of attention, and many people have been committed to the cause. Although Polio was a major problem in Africa in the 2000â€™s, the problem has been slowly brought under control. August 11 of 2015 marked the first time in history when there was not a single recorded case in the entire continent of Africa. This means that Africa has been polio-free for over a year and a half. Although other diseases caused by viruses may bring the attention away from polio, this is unlikely, as many organizations, such as the World Health Organization (WHO) have stressed the importance of completely eradicating the Wild Poliovirus.

Passage of time. But rising more slowly -- in fact, dropping a bit -- now that I'm taking into account the coming of the "high" season for polio, and the thoughts expressed in the most pessimistic top predictions. Will try to rise steadily from here.

WHO have pioneered efforts to contain rogue viruses in Africa. Polio has been contained for a year (not one single case) as of August 2014. In 2013 Global Polio Eradication Initiative launched a campaign to completely rid polio.

Africa has been free of polio since mid-2014. The public health efforts have been highly successful and there is no reason to believe that the direction could be reversed. However, there is a chance that a vaccine could mutate again and cause additional cases.

I believe that there is a small chance of a wild outbreak of poliovirus before the end of this year due to the improve vaccines and new technologies, the government communication, and the new protocol of these countries when a case occurs.  August 11, marked a year without polio, and there have only been 2 countries who have not stopped the poliovirus ever and those two countries are not in Africa.  I give this an 8% chance of happening because disease can spread and ebola recently spread throughout Africa recently, however due to all the new organizations, vaccinations, and the protocols in place I give this a small chance of this happening

My prediction: 90%
Africa is such an unsanitary place and not even the joint cooperation of many countries can completely remove the virus, it will still prevail, even in just a small population. But since ‘free’ means 97% not having the virus, 3% of Africa’s population is still a large amount of people for this virus to infect. And there hasn’t been a known case of the wild poliovirus in a year and a half in Africa.

People are looking pretty hard for the virus and there are very good surveillance systems in place - if they have not found any so far its unlikely they will. They only danger is influx of refugees from Afghanistan or Pakistan (last two areas where Polio is circulating outside Africa) into North Africa - which is highly unlikely, but if Europe cuts off migration, that is a possibility.
Still wild poliovirus free in Africa with less than 10 months to go!

Affirming, but with the caution that this is no sure thing.  Actually, I think I'm a little too high on this forecast.  There's a lot of time left.  I might be over the edge.  Civil disorder exists in so many places in Africa, and it has such a negative impact on public health work.
If they switch to inactivated vaccines now as requested by the physicians.
Just staying above consensus. Biology is unpredictable but I think recurrence is quite unlikely and each passing day decreases the chances both from a time and a biological perspective.
Continuing to adjust upward as the chance lowers given no spread to date beyond Pakistan and India. Africa remains unaffected and it seems the cases are contained.
Moving up a bit, mainly reflecting the elimination of Type 2 and the upcoming switch to bi-valent vaccines. Afghanistan and Pakistan continue as the two remaining reservoirs.

In 2014, WPV (wild polio virus) reappeared in seven countries previously given the all clear[1], so reinfection is certainly possible. The only two countries with on-going infections of WPV are Pakistan and Afghanistan, with a total of 6 reported cases between them. Vaccination efforts are on-going, but it's difficult in areas facing unrest. There is also a case of circulating vaccine-derived polio virus (cVDPV) to contend with, though the vaccinations causing this are being phased out.
Still wild poliovirus free in Africa with less than 10 months to go!

Going below consensus given the headache caused by vaccine switch. The article at http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMp1514467 lists a non-trivial increase in relative risk for vaccine-caused disease and / or resurfacing of type 2 wild type virus. Absolute risk is low, even after the increase, but we are trying to predict one case in one billion.

11 mths is a long time in Africa

Reaffirming, but followers beware.  I'm away this month to places with sketchy internet so I haven't been posting as often.  I spoke with an African guy yesterday who tried to sell me a pile of cast copper bronze items from the Dogon culture.  This may seem to be an irrelevant experience, but bear with me.  The items were representational human figures of various types.  He told me they came from Niger and Mali.  You can check examples of Dogon artifacts displayed in major museums.  Another source, the Saturday edition of the WSJ, tells the sad tale of what you could call the new evangelical form of Islam that is creating mahem in these countries.  The small story effect is that fearful people are packing up bundles of representational sculpture and selling them for scrap because they don't want to get caught with anti-Islamic items that depict the human form.  The big story effect is chaos across the mid-section of the continent.  If you sweep these disparate pieces together, you come back around to the main concern for this question.   War and civil disorder can mess up the great work being done by public health authorities.  There are so many places in Africa where social disintegration reigns, and in many of these places media attention is sparse.  There is a lot of population movement.  I'm still betting on a positive result for this question, but it's no sure thing.

This link:  "For the first time in history, Africa has had 4-months without any wild or circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus cases, nor any environmental positive sample."       http://www.polioeradication.org/dataandmonitoring/poliothisweek.aspx

Increasing to 50% with passage of time and latest WHO news.  Still more skeptical on this question than consensus because of concern for weak public health systems and widespread "ungoverned spaces" in Africa:
Updating for passage of time and no news of a spread of the poliovirus.
I want to also factor in the concern of previously undetected and unreported wild polio cases in Africa for 2015.

There were 0 cases of native wild polio in Africa in 2015, 6 in 2014 (in Nigeria)  and 50 (in Nigeria) in 2013.  
In 2015 there were 66 wild polio cases in the world: all in  Afghanistan and Pakistan. with no importations to other countries.    There were 19 cases imported to other countries in 2014.  17 of these were in Africa.  This is down from 224 cases imported to Africa in 2013.  (http://www.polioeradication.org/Mediaroom/NewsletterPolioNews.aspx)

The overall likelihood seems overstated.   What is the relationship of the level of immunization in the diverse populations of Africa relative to the level required to end the transmission of the virus?  If local conditions are varied and complex then could there be a possibility of silent circulation without symptoms over the time period of the question.  For Africa (Nigeria, Somalia) it seems possible that the extent of immunization is hard to ascertain in the local populations and that there could be some silent circulation.  Kalkowska, Tebbens, Pallansch, Cochi, Wassilak, and Thompson (BMC Infectious Diseases, 2015, 15:66) raise this issue and suggest that a longer time period may be necessary to achieve 95% confidence about eradication.

Polio has a very long dormancy period, and although we have not seen it for years, it can come back.  Additionally, there is a small chance that live-virus vaccines could reintroduce cases to the population http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/19/6/13-0080_article.  I don't know if this counts as 'wild' by this questions definition however.  However, with a little luck and decent vaccine networks, we should not see any polio in the near future.

Moving up from 60% on 11 December, for passage of time.

As of 2015, most of, if not all, of the the polio cases were vaccine derived cases, not wild. On top of this, there were not that many cases in 2015.  Polio is very infectious and has a history of making comebacks which is why i put my forecast at 87%.
Advances in medicine and virus must be contained to avoid a pandemic.
Advances in medicine and virus must be contained to avoid a pandemic.
This raises many issues and past attempts to eradicate these types of epidemics:
No news has been good news, so I'll follow the crowd a bit.

The incidence of wild polio virus infection continues to decrease around the world and is only endemic in 2 countries, Afghanistan and Pakistan!
The main concern is infection from circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus (cVDPV) which is usually due to type 2 polio virus. 
In 4 months all countries still using the oral polio virus vaccine will be switching from trivalent vaccine to bivalent vaccine that will remove the type 2 attenuated virus to lower the risk of cVDPV.

The most recent numbers at the polio eradication link (above & here)  http://www.polioeradication.org/dataandmonitoring/poliothisweek.aspx
show only Pakistan and Afghanistan with cases of wild type polio virus infection in 2015.     To cause wild type polio infection in Africa infected travelers from a high risk area would have to bring the virus and infect susceptible individuals in Africa.   A goggle search could not identify this movement as likely.
Poliovirus is still an issue in Pakistan and India but Africa remains free. Some passage of time has occurred and no overly informative news.

no cases for over a year makes infection unlikely, not least because the african 'patient 0-again' (if you will) would most likely have to travel outside the continent to catch it and africans are unlikely to travel to LEDCs where such viruses are endemic or even meaningfully present. In addition to which, successful NIDs throughout the continent will provide herd immunity.

Reading more into population movements and the risk of reintroducing the virus into Africa (which is certainly considered "at risk"), I am going to lower my forecast substantially. My research is summed up well in one article below:

I have seen a handful of stories as of late declaring cases of wild poliovirus as rumors and false in India, Russia and Tajikistan. Africa will officially be certified polio-free once Nigeria is polio-free. I will thus focus my efforts on Nigeria firstly and Africa as a whole subsequently. Nigeria was removed from the polio endemic list in October. The question becomes, will they maintain this status through 12/31/16? Given the remarkable data and trend, my momentum and trend-following indicators suggest a strong yes. However, given the length of time and other variables, I lower my confidence but will be updating forecasts with any news.

2 full years of no cases of polio is required before eradication can be declared as complete in Africa, and only a few countries in Asia still have active cases of polio, so there is a better than even chance of success now!

Lots of positive news on this front. However, I am starting low because of concern that security concerns/ state instability risks across the continent - esp. Somalia, Nigeria, and across the Sahel - suggests weakened public health initiatives. Also, there is the risk that extremists may deliberately target health workers to slow/stop immunization campaigns as they have in Pakistan (where 32 workers have been killed since 2012, according to WHO).
I'm beginning my forecasting here by educating myself here:
Moving up from 55% on 12 November, for passage of time.

Affirming prior. I want to be optimistic, but with the data posted by lk12345, there were three countries last years that reported wild cases. Thinking that all three will go down to zero this year and next may be too optimistic. Note: all three countries last reported wild cases in spring of 2014. If we get past spring of 2016 with no new cases, I'll raise my prob.

Uping my score slightly because of information from this Pdf with list of World wide cases of wild Poliovirus as of 1st December 2015.

Of the three wild polio viruses, the New York Times reported yesterday that only one type of wild polio virus is believed to exist now, and it is found only in Afghanistan and Pakistan. Health experts are so confident of this that they are considering switching to a monovalent vaccine. It is possible that some vector could bring that strain of polio to Africa, but the likelihood is small.

Only 56 cases of wild poliovirus in the world so far this year.  Down from 290 by this time last year.  It is believed only 1 of the 3 wild polioviruses strains still exists.  I think they will do this.
http://www.nytimes.com/2015/11/24/health/a-move-closer-to-total-disappearance-of-polio.html?_r=0

Anneinak: In answer to your question, I was at 21% and went down to 15% after reading the global initiative Oct. report, but now I am waffling after our exchanges. You mentioned your Merck manual, are you a nurse? I am a BSN-RN PHN, but a very green new grad, with absolutely no experience yet, still looking for my first job. The only thing I have to inform me on this question are the most basic 101 classes in microbiology and pathophysiology, an overview of the public health model and what I learned in those classes makes me want to keep my forecast very low, and be very pessimistic. On the other hand, I look at the wonderful progress that has been made world wide since the eradication programs started in 1988, and in Africa, I see that there has been no diagnosed WPV for 2015 and I wonder if it’s possible that they have pulled off an incredible achievement that was targeted for 2019. If not, they are sooooo close. They are approaching the finish line. I guess that’s why the powers-that-be at GJ picked this topic for a question, curse you GJ powers! (shakes fist in air). 
Still, at the end of it all, the final success of polio eradication in Africa depends on how well the following countries (identified as “states no longer infected by wild poliovirus, but which remain vulnerable to international spread” Cameroon, Equatorial Guinea, Ethiopia, Nigeria, and Somalia.  http://www.polioeradication.org/Keycountries/PolioEmergency.aspx) have complied with the plans and recommendations given over the last couple of years, and this necessitates a knowledge of their recent history of political and social conditions, and the state of their public health programs. Also, I should think the amount of concern, and public funds dedicated to the cause by governments plays a big part.
 I stand by my statements previously about the precarious and tenuous state of the whole campaign at this twilight moment before polio sets like the sun on the world horizon. Any disengagement by authorities, gaps in meeting quotas, slip ups, health care personnel problems, non-conforming to the action plans could easily manifest as individual or small outbreaks of polio somewhere. The sense of concern and warning about this is very noticeable in the October Global Eradication Initiative report. 
So, more research digging around in google is called for, I have decided to go back up to 20% and sit there while researching how well these countries have carried out their eradication programs as best I can. I may possibly adjust depending on what I find, and I will certainly share anything interesting with you! It has been fun having these exchanges, and very helpful.
I’m also going to re-visit and rummage around more in these links that have been my main sources:
Wiki article with helpful chart on R0 number and HIT percentages (explained in “mechanics” section of the article ) https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Herd_immunity
The good ole CDC  http://www.cdc.gov/polio/
The Global Polio Eradication Initiative   http://www.polioeradication.org/
WHO  http://www.who.int/features/factfiles/polio/en/

Here's a few excerpts below from the October report of the Global Polio Eradication Initiative. We are entering the low season for polio. Next May is the start of the high season, and I think the results of this year's immunization efforts may not have  have repercussions until then, and unfortunately, it seems the ball was dropped a little this year, or at least the initiative report didn't note the markers that would have predicted a polio free season in 2016. In fact the report sounds rather pessimistic. Therefore, with this in mind, and also knowing that the ebola crisis likely has whomped the health care systems and government resources of some other African countries that had successful immunization programs,  I am reducing my forecast to 15%.

Here's a few excerpts below from the October report of the Global Polio Eradication Initiative. We are entering the low season for polio. Next May is the start of the high season, and I think the results of this year's immunization efforts may not have  have repercussions until then, and unfortunately, it seems the ball was dropped a little this year, or at least the initiative report didn't note the markers that would have predicted a polio free season in 2016. In fact the report sounds rather pessimistic. Therefore, with this in mind, and also knowing that the ebola crisis likely has whomped the health care systems and government resources of some other African countries that had successful immunization programs,  I am reducing my forecast to 15%.

Adjusting to be a bit more optimistic. I'd been keeping this number lower given the warnings about the risk of resurgence by health officials -- but it now occurs to me that there's a chance that health officials have an incentive to overstate the risk (in order to keep attention focused on the problem, in order to keep funding, etc.) This doesn't mean that they *are* necessarily overstating the risk -- in fact, I don't think it's likely that they are -- but I'm going to put a bit less weight on their warnings as an adjustment.

Following Khalid, mostly -- they seem to have spent a lot of time thinking about this, and they have the same concerns I do. This is an interesting question, because as time goes on, two opposing factors determine the risk:

Africa is unlikely to stay wild polio-free through 12/31/2016.  Please see http://www.popsci.com/article/science/reemergence-polio-global-health-risk for some background.  Especially due to flows of migrants from Syria (where polio has had recent outbreaks), and due to past outbreaks in countries such as Cameroon and the Central African Republic,  I think that the risk of a wild case is reasonably high.  In any country with significant unrest or instability, vaccination programs can be difficult to implement, leading to risk of the disease spreading again.

After doing some reading, I didn't want to say "I don't know" and predict 50%.  I went through five pages worth of predictions on this site, and ran a regression of briar score vs. predictions. (For people who made multiple predictions, I only used their most recent.)  This returned a y-intercept of 50%.  I removed one obvious outlier and got 45%. Removing a second outlier got me 46%.

The answer to this question depends on immediate factors (is there any health professional to take notice) and on past security problems (were there vaccines available in the past years). Countries that have seen recent troubles, but improved recently, are likely to report new polio cases. In Africa, Somalia fits the bill. Last year, Somalia was still caught in the final purge of Al-Shabab, which may have affected vaccination. This year, security has improved, possibly leading to better polio reporting.

Poliovirus is spread mainly through fecal-oral transmission and to a lesser extent, via the oral-oral route. Basic sanitation and access to clean water is necessary to help curb the spread of infections and the lack of either of these can support low level transmission. Moreover, viral shedding can still occur in individuals who have been vaccinated ( http://www.livescience.com/52004-polio-virus-gut-shedding.html ), even for almost 30 years as in the linked UK case. At the same time, humans are the only natural known hosts of the virus, which potentially eliminates other species as wild reservoirs ( http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0042682205005830 ).

Polio is such a tough disease to control.  Even highly advanced countries like Israeli have found it (by surprise) in their sewage.  It was significant enough such that Israel considered adding a vaccination with the live virus after patients received the inactive version.

First impression guess here, 80.  There have been 13 months polio-free, but in one out of the last 14 months (the one longest ago) there was a case of polio.  The time frame is 16 months to go.  100 percent /14 months = 7 percent chance a month (high) down to a zero percent chance (low) if you'd like to believe it's eradicated, no way it could spread from elsewhere, etc.  7 percent a month leaves a 93 percent chance it hasn't happened by next month to the power of 16 months leaves a 29 percent chance of Africa being polio-free after 16 months.  If I split the difference between 29 and 100 percent, since I think a seven percent chance a month is too high, I get 64.5 (remarkably similar to someone else's guess).  If I split the difference between 0 percent and 7 percent, and go with (1.00-.035)^16, that works out to 54.6 percent.  However, what do we know about eradication of other diseases, or any other analagous cases?  If the per-month chance of it coming back is really only 2 percent, then the advance probability of continued eradication by then is "really" closer to 72 percent.  And if you figure a 2 percent chance this month, but only a one percent change 8 months from now, and only a .5 percent chance 8 months after that (probably closer to how a good actuarial model of these events might really look), then the probability of longer-term eradication only goes up from there.  Some research into past cases of disease eradication might clarify what the marginal probability each month really might be, and better frame the overall chances.

And if you figure a 2 percent chance this month, but only a one percent change 8 months from now, and only a .5 percent chance 8 months after that (probably closer to how a good actuarial model of these events might really look), then the probability of longer-term eradication only goes up from there.  Some research into past cases of disease eradication might clarify what the marginal probability each month really might be, and better frame the overall chances.

It's been a year since there has been a confirmed case. They are working hard to keep it that way. But, there were a number of cases in 2013 and 2014, so I think the chance of a relapse here is   signifivcant. My quick sense is that risk is about 30%, though it declines with the passage of time.
